title: Parts of Speech
summary: The categories words belong to based on their role in a sentence.
details:
There are 8 main parts of speech:
1. Noun – names (boy, school)
2. Pronoun – replaces a noun (he, they)
3. Verb – shows action or state (run, is)
4. Adjective – describes a noun (red, tall)
5. Adverb – describes a verb/adjective (quickly, very)
6. Preposition – shows relationship (in, on)
7. Conjunction – joins words or phrases (and, but)
8. Interjection – expresses strong feeling (wow!, oh!)

title: Tenses
summary: The time an action takes place: past, present, or future.
details:
Three main types of tenses:
1. Present – action happening now (She walks to school.)
2. Past – action happened before (She walked to school.)
3. Future – action will happen (She will walk to school.)
Each tense has four forms: simple, continuous, perfect, and perfect continuous.

title: Active and Passive Voice
summary: Two ways to write a sentence depending on the focus.
details:
Active Voice – the subject does the action. (The teacher explained the lesson.)
Passive Voice – the action is done to the subject. (The lesson was explained by the teacher.)
Tip: Use active voice for clarity, passive voice when the doer is unknown or less important.

title: Figures of Speech
summary: Creative expressions used to make language more interesting.
details:
Common figures of speech:
1. Simile – compares using 'like' or 'as' (Her smile is like the sun.)
2. Metaphor – direct comparison (Time is money.)
3. Personification – giving human qualities to non-human things (The wind whispered.)
4. Hyperbole – exaggeration (I’ve told you a million times.)

title: Punctuation Rules
summary: Marks that help clarify meaning in writing.
details:
Common punctuation marks:
- Period (.) – ends a sentence.
- Comma (,) – separates ideas or items in a list.
- Question Mark (?) – shows a question.
- Exclamation Mark (!) – shows strong feeling.
- Apostrophe (') – shows possession or contraction (it's, John's).
- Quotation Marks ("") – show direct speech.

title: Synonyms and Antonyms
summary: Words with similar or opposite meanings.
details:
Synonyms – words with similar meanings (big/large, happy/glad).
Antonyms – words with opposite meanings (hot/cold, fast/slow).
Tip: Using synonyms makes writing more interesting; using antonyms shows contrast.

title: Direct and Indirect Speech
summary: Two ways to report what someone said.
details:
Direct Speech – exact words spoken. (He said, 'I am tired.')
Indirect Speech – rephrasing the words without quotes. (He said he was tired.)
Rules:
- Change pronouns and tenses in indirect speech.
- Remove quotation marks.

title: Commonly Confused Words
summary: Words that look or sound alike but have different meanings.
details:
Examples:
- Their (belonging to them) vs There (place) vs They're (they are)
- Affect (verb: to influence) vs Effect (noun: result)
- Accept (receive) vs Except (excluding)
Tip: Learn common pairs to avoid mistakes in writing.
